clusters.title: Landmark climate report shows 'every Australian has a lot at stake', minister says – video
clusters.neutral_headline: Climate Report Highlights Australian Risks
bullet_summary: Every Australian, regardless of where they live, has a lot at stake,' said Bowen
Reported by Guardian Australia, 9News, ABC News Australia

items.title: Landmark climate report shows 'every Australian has a lot at stake', minister says – video
items.standfirst: Chris Bowen, the climate change minister, held a press conference after the release of a new report that finds no Australian community would be immune from the risks of worsening climate change. 'One thing that is very clear from this climate assessment is that the whole country has a lot at stake. Every Australian, regardless of where they live, has a lot at stake,' said Bowen. The long-awaited national climate risk assessment provides the most detailed picture of the severe and far-reaching social and economic impact of the climate crisis for Australia.► Subscribe to Guardian Australia on YouTubeMillions of Australians at risk from rising sea levels and heat deaths could soar, landmark climate report warns Continue reading...
items.content: Chris Bowen, the climate change minister, held a press conference after the release of a new report that finds no Australian community would be immune from the risks of worsening climate change. 'One thing that is very clear from this climate assessment is that the whole country has a lot at stake. Every Australian, regardless of where they live, has a lot at stake,' said Bowen. The long-awaited national climate risk assessment provides the most detailed picture of the severe and far-reaching social and economic impact of the climate crisis for Australia.► Subscribe to Guardian Australia on YouTubeMillions of Australians at risk from rising sea levels and heat deaths could soar, landmark climate report warns Continue reading...

items.title: Heatwave deaths to soar, 1.5 million Aussies at risk of flooding: climate report
items.standfirst: Australia's first climate risk assessment released today has detailed some of the biggest natural threats facing the nation as the global average temperature ramps up.
items.content: Around 1.5 million Australians will be at risk of sea level rise by 2050, according to a dire inaugural climate risk assessment.Australia's first National Climate Risk Assessment (NCRA), released today, has detailed some of the biggest natural threats facing the nation as the global average temperature ramps up.The report found even just 1.5 degrees of warming would raise sea levels by 0.14 metres.READ MORE: 'Note' left by Charlie Kirk shooting suspect under investigation"By 2050, the number of coastal communities located in high and very-high risk areas will increase from 8 per cent to 18 per cent due to sea level rise," the report states."If current populations remained as they are today, this would represent an increase to 1.5 million people at risk."The assessment also noted that 34 per cent of coastal communities could be at risk by 2090 – a total of three million Australians.READ MORE: These siblings started a business with a few hundred bucks. It's made $20 millionThe report looked at three key warming scenarios in Australia: 1.5 degrees, 2 degrees and three degrees of warming.It found the planet is heading towards 2.9 degrees of warming by 2030.Warming of this level would result in heatwave deaths skyrocketing by 444 per cent in Sydney and 423 per cent in Darwin.READ MORE: Teacher who beat cancer killed in tragic jet ski accidentThe rising temperatures will then increase the risk of communicable diseases from mosquitos and ticks."Public health risks will become more pronounced, with a significant potential for loss of life and strain on health systems," the report noted.Among the natural disasters and environmental crises we could face as temperatures rise are more frequent category 4 and 5 cyclones, large hail on the east coast and an increased risk of bushfires in forested areas.Dangerous fire weather days are projected to become more frequent in southern and eastern areas too.The assessment also noted 63 "nationally significant" climate risks.These include threats to Australia's Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples, risks to infrastructure, mental health impacts and loss of animal species.Minister for Climate Change and Energy Chris Bowen said the report made it clear that vulnerable Australians in rural communities will bear the brunt of climate change."Whether it be cropping, cattle sheep, fisheries… the report makes clear that Australia's regional areas will be big losers from climate change," Bowen said."We are living [through] climate change now, it's no longer a forecast, projection, or prediction."It is a lived reality. It is too late to avoid any impact now. But it's not too late to avoid the worst of the impacts."The financial impact of climate change in Australia is predicted to be astronomical.Losses in property value could soar to $611 billion by 2050 and may reach $770 billion by 2090.Disaster costs for each state and territory for flood, bushfire, storm surge and tropical cyclones for a moderate emissions scenario (+1.5 degrees ) could reach an annual cost of $40.3 billion by 2050 too.DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

items.title: Millions of Australians at risk from rising sea levels and heat deaths to soar, national climate risk assessment report warns
items.standfirst: National climate risk assessment report finds heat-related deaths would surge 450% in Sydney if global heating surpasses 3CFollow our Australia news live blog for latest updatesGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastThe number of heat-related deaths in Sydney could surge by almost 450% if global heating surpasses 3C, according to a landmark report that finds no Australian community would be immune from the “cascading, compounding and concurrent” risks of a worsening climate.The report also lays bare the heightened risk from rising sea levels on Australia’s populous coastal communities, including flooding, erosion and inundation. Continue reading...
items.content: National climate risk assessment report finds heat-related deaths would surge 450% in Sydney if global heating surpasses 3CFollow our Australia news live blog for latest updatesGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastThe number of heat-related deaths in Sydney could surge by almost 450% if global heating surpasses 3C, according to a landmark report that finds no Australian community would be immune from the “cascading, compounding and concurrent” risks of a worsening climate.The report also lays bare the heightened risk from rising sea levels on Australia’s populous coastal communities, including flooding, erosion and inundation. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Behind these airlocked doors, Australian scientists study deadly diseases
clusters.neutral_headline: Australian Scientists Study Deadly Diseases in Secure Labs

items.title: Behind these airlocked doors, Australian scientists study deadly diseases
items.standfirst: Step into one of Australia's few biosafety level 4 facilities, where scientists handle highly transmissible and potentially lethal pathogens such as Ebola and Hendra virus.
items.content: Step into one of Australia's few biosafety level 4 facilities, where scientists handle highly transmissible and potentially lethal pathogens such as Ebola and Hendra virus.

ai_summary: Australian scientists study deadly diseases.
They work in biosafety level 4 facilities.
The facilities handle dangerous pathogens.
Examples include Ebola and Hendra virus.
The labs have airlocked doors for safety.

items.title: Rideshare drivers bypassing fatigue restrictions as cost-of-living hits
items.standfirst: According to the Transport Workers' Union, some rideshare drivers have reported being on the road for up to 18 hours a day, swapping between multiple apps in order to bypass fatigue restrictions.
items.content: According to the Transport Workers' Union, some rideshare drivers have reported being on the road for up to 18 hours a day, swapping between multiple apps in order to bypass fatigue restrictions.

ai_summary: Transport Workers' Union reports some rideshare drivers work up to eighteen hours daily.
Drivers reportedly switch between multiple apps to avoid fatigue regulations.
The cost of living crisis is cited as a contributing factor to the extended hours.
Concerns exist regarding driver safety and potential risks associated with fatigue.
The union is advocating for stricter enforcement of existing regulations.

items.title: Dads avoid sex talks with kids amid concern about online content
items.standfirst: New report finds mothers do more of the sex education at home, raising concerns that young boys are missing out on key information from their dads.
items.content: New report finds mothers do more of the sex education at home, raising concerns that young boys are missing out on key information from their dads.

ai_summary: A new report indicates mothers handle most sex education at home.
Concerns arise that young boys are missing key information from their fathers.
The report highlights a gender disparity in parental involvement.
The study suggests a need for increased fatherly engagement in sex education.
The research aims to understand the dynamics of family sex education.

items.content: Immigration has become a new fault line inside the Liberal Party that will erupt again.

ai_summary: Immigration has become a point of contention within the Liberal Party.
Some Liberals believe Australia is accepting the wrong immigrants.
The issue is expected to resurface and cause further division.

The internal conflict could impact the party's future strategies.
